Objectives
Failure analysis is the science and technique of understanding how materials and products fail. Whenever a component no longer performs its intended function, it is beneficial to understand how and why it has failed. Analyzing failures is a critical process in determining the physical root causes of problems. Failure analysis is a critical part of understanding what went wrong, what could have been done to prevent the failure, and how one might prevent similar failures in the future. The main objectives of conducting failure analysis are as follows:
1. Accurately identifying the root cause(s) of the failure
2. Identify and execute effective containment, corrective, and preventive action plans to prevent future failures
3. Accurately identify a schedule of execution of containment, root cause(s) identification and validation, corrective, and preventive actions, and driving Performance Against Schedule
Scope
This procedure is applicable to any part, material, or assembly provided by a Supplier or designed and manufactured by ASM, up to and including a systemic failure within the context of our system-level product operating successfully in the customer’s use case and environment, for which failure analysis is requested by a Customer or ASM Field Service Engineer, Process Engineer, Key Product Unit (KPU), or other party.
The FA process includes:
· Requesting failure analysis
· Approving failure analysis cases
· Part movement
· Creating a failure analysis plan
· Performing failure analysis to the FA Plan, using Effective Problem Solving (EPS)
· Correctly identifying root cause(s)
· Identifying effective corrective and preventive actions and execution schedule
· Creating a failure analysis report
· Executing defined corrective and preventive actions
· Closing a failure analysis investigation

Master Inspection Characteristics (MIC):
MICs are predefined attributes or parameters that need to be inspected, such as dimensions, weight, or color.

MICs are linked to sampling procedures and inspection methods to define how and what to inspect.

It includes the master inspection characteristics (MICs), sampling procedures, and inspection methods.
The sampling plan ensures that all necessary inspections are performed consistently and according to predefined standards.

A sampling scheme is used within the Quality Management (QM) module to determine the sample size for an inspection based on various factors such as lot size, inspection severity, and Acceptable Quality Level (AQL).

Dynamic Modification Rule (DMR):
DMRs adjust the inspection scope based on the quality history of the supplier or product. They help in dynamically changing the inspection severity (e.g., from normal to reduced) based on past inspection results.
DMRs are associated with sampling procedures to modify the sample size and inspection frequency dynamically.

Creating inspection method
In SAP, an inspection method is a key component within the Quality Management (QM) module. It defines the procedure for inspecting a characteristic and ensures consistency and standardization in quality inspections. Here are the main functions of an inspection method in SAP:
Standardization:Inspection methods help standardize the inspection process across different plants and departments by providing a consistent approach to inspecting specific characteristics.
Assignment to Characteristics:They can be assigned to master inspection characteristics or directly to inspection characteristics in an inspection plan, ensuring that the correct inspection procedures are followed.
Documentation: Inspection methods include detailed instructions and criteria for performing inspections, which can be documented and linked to relevant documents, such as drawings or specific inspection instructions.
Quality Control:By defining the inspection procedures, inspection methods help maintain quality control and ensure that products meet specified standards and requirements.
Efficiency:Using predefined inspection methods can streamline the inspection process, reduce errors, and improve overall efficiency in quality management.

In SAP, creating an equipment task list within the Plant Maintenance (PM) module serves several important functions:
Centralized Maintenance Tasks:
Equipment task lists allow you to centrally define and manage maintenance tasks for specific pieces of equipment. This ensures that all maintenance activities are standardized and consistently applied.
Efficiency in Planning: By using equipment task lists, you can plan recurring maintenance activities more effectively. This saves time when creating maintenance orders and maintenance plans, as the predefined tasks can be quickly applied.
Standardization: Task lists help standardize maintenance procedures across different pieces of equipment, ensuring that the same high standards are maintained throughout the organization.
Simplified Maintenance Management: Any updates or changes to the task list are automatically reflected in all associated maintenance plans and orders. This simplifies the management and ensures that all maintenance activities are up-to-date.
Integration with Maintenance Plans: Equipment task lists can be integrated into maintenance plans, allowing for systematic scheduling and execution of maintenance tasks.

Record Results: Document the results of each calibration, including any adjustments made and whether the equipment passed or failed the calibration

Sales Order with Letter of Credit (LC)
· For Sales Order which payment terms using letter of credit (LC), Sales Operation team need to change the LC relevant payment terms and save the sales order. Enhancement (RICEFW) will be required to indicate that the Sales Order is not relevant for credit check, and to apply a delivery block so subsequent documents (delivery, post goods issue, billing) are not able to be created.[ES1] [ES2]
· Once the ‘Letter of Credit’ is received by Finance Share Service (FSS), SU1 Finance will manually release the delivery block to allow the creation of subsequent documents (post goods issue, billing). Workflow (RICEFW) is triggered upon creation of the Delivery Order, this workflow is to enable SU1 Finance to unblock the Delivery Order with LC payment terms differentiated from the standard delivery block executed by Sales Operations Team.
· Indicated below is the end to end step for Sales Order with LC and the subsequent downstream impact for awareness of Business Controller:
1. CSR will create Sales Order created with the LC payment term.
2. This Sales Order created with the LC will still allow outbound delivery to be created.
3. Logistics team create delivery order.
4. System will check if delivery order created has LC payment terms. The system logic is picking up from the Reference Document under Predecessor Data (refer to below screenshot). This is link from the original Sales Order’s Payment Terms.
5. Workflow will be triggered, and delivery block will be applied from Delivery Order.
6. Email notification is sent to Sales Operations team, FSS AR team and SU1 Finance to notify that Delivery Order with LC is created. Once FSS AR team received the LC, they need to notify SU1 Finance team to release the delivery block.
7. Once delivery block is released, Logistics team can proceed with Post Goods Issue.

Description:
The GR/IR clearing account is used in Materials Management, where all goods and invoice receipts are recorded. If amounts and prices match, they are automatically cleared. Clearing of GR/IR items is essential in accurate tracking of financial records and supplier relationship management, to fulfill orders or payments on time. However, not all items can be cleared automatically due to reasons like mismatched amounts or missing invoice and receipt.
The GR/IR account reconciliation process is an exception-handling process to resolve discrepancies between. S/4HANA enhances this process by displaying all necessary data in an analytical Fiori app (Monitor GR/IR Account Reconciliation), enabling easier documentation of processing steps and statuses.
